The purpose of this document is to outline and define the service provision within the Cardiac Centre at Broomfield Hospital as part of MEHT.

The policy sets out the roles and responsibilities, processes to be followed and establishes good practice guidelines to assist staff in the effective utilisation of the services provided by the Cardiac Centre at MEHT.
Aims of the Service

The Cardiac Centre is located on Level 2 of the PFI Building (A210) and is a purpose built area to provide high quality, safe, patient centred cardiac care and investigation to the population of Mid Essex living in and around the Chelmsford, Maldon and Braintree Districts (approximately 380,000), both in the outpatient, inpatient and elective day case setting.

To ensure that all patients referred for cardiac investigations and services have access to Consultant Cardiologists, Specialist Registrars, Cardiac Physiologists and Cardiac Nurse Specialists, both in the outpatient referral setting, via the direct access route from General Practitioners and also whilst as an inpatient within MEHT.

To be responsive to requirements for inpatient cardiology consultation and inpatient cardiac investigation requests from other clinical teams, in order to facilitate appropriate specialist management of cardiac conditions and assist in timely patient discharge or transfer for additional services where required.

Cardiology Outpatient Clinics
Inclusion Criteria

Cardiology Services are available to all adults (Aged over 16 Years) living in the catchment area of Mid Essex NHS Hospital Services Trust (MEHT), inclusive of the Chelmsford, Maldon and Braintree Districts.

Limited Cardiology Services are available to Paediatric Patients (Under 16 Years) (12 Lead Electrocardiogram/Ambulatory ECG Monitoring) via direct referral from General Practitioners or Paediatricians.
Exclusion Criteria
Complex Paediatric Cardiac services are not performed.

Key Operational Requirements
5.1.1 Appropriate environment to provide a range of invasive and non-invasive Cardiac Investigations safely and efficiently, including temperature control and dimmable lighting.
5.1.2 Appropriate equipment to provide a range of invasive and non-invasive Cardiac Investigations safely and efficiently.
5.1.3 Access to Trust Clinical Systems to review patient records and record and document investigations performed, including:

5.1.3 Access to facilities to admit patients for emergency inpatient care from Outpatient or Elective investigations if required.
5.1.4 Access to facilities to enable transfer of patients to other levels of care for example to General High Dependency Unit for those with Temporary Pacing Wires In Situ.
5.1.5 Access to enable transfer of patients to specialist centres for ongoing care, for example to The Essex Cardiothoracic Centre (ECTC).
5.1.6 Access to appropriate resuscitation equipment (Adult and Paediatric) in the event of an emergency, including defibrillators with a pacing capability.

5.1.6 Good Security measures to enable staff to perform a range of invasive and non- invasive Cardiac Investigations safely and efficiently, including safety provisions for working outside of normal working hours and lone working.
5.1.7 Access to ICT Systems and Telephone Systems.
5.1.8 Access to drinking water facilities for both patients and staff.

Staffing
Staffing Profile – Cardiac Centre (Cardiac Physiology)
Security Requirements
There must be a safe and secure working environment for staff
All staff are screened appropriately via HR through CRB checks prior to being allowed patient contact.
The Lone Worker Policy applies and should be adhered to for all staff working within the Cardiac Centre alone.
Data Protection, Confidentiality and Appropriate Use of IT Policies should be complied with at all times.
All staff are provided with a Name Badge which must be worn and clearly visible at all time whilst on clinical duty.
All staff are provided with and must carry Trust Identification at all times.
All staff are responsible for their own personal information such as secure log in details and passwords, including their Trust smartcards.

Manual Handling
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Manual Handling Policy and Protocols.
All Staff receive mandatory manual handling training and are required to ensure that this competency is maintained in line with trust policy and departmental protocols.
Fire Safety
The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and departmental procedures.
The department has a nominated Fire Safety Officer, who is responsible for the safe and efficient management of the service and any relevant actions as a result of a fire or fire safety instruction.
All Staff receive mandatory fire safety training and are required to ensure that this competency is maintained in line with trust policy and departmental protocols.
Radiation Protection (Staff working within Cardiac Angiography Suite)

All staff working in the Cardiac Angiography Suite will wear radiation protective clothing/equipment in the form of Lead Aprons, Thyroid Shields and wear appropriate lead lined glasses if deemed necessary.

All staff working in close range to radiation will be issued with and required to wear radiation dose badges, one to be worn at the gonad level beneath the lead apron and another to be worn outside of the apron on the collar at thyroid level.

Radiation Badges will be changed on a monthly basis by the radiation protection supervisor and dose records recorded. Anyone who receives a reading that exceeds 3/10ths of the recommended monthly radiation limit will be informed, and if this level is consistently exceeded his or her working practices will be investigated by the Radiation Protection Supervisor.
All staff operating radiation equipment should have appropriate training and have completed the IRMER course run by the trust.
Special precautions may be adopted for radiation in pregnancy
Infection Prevention
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliant to all Trust Infection Prevention Policies.
Training and Education
The Hospital provides a library facility that is accessible to all trust staff for the purposes of training and development.
All staff training will be delivered in line with the Trust's Mandatory Training Policy and Training Needs Analysis.

All Cardiac Centre staff are individually responsible and are expected to ensure they are compliant with the Trust's Mandatory Training Programme relative to their job role, including resuscitation training.
All staff will attend Mandatory Training Days as required.

All specialist staff training will be competency based, organised and monitored by Heads of Service, including monthly echocardiography audits in line with BSE Protocols and attendance to specialist training courses or conferences.
It is the responsibility of the Principal and Chief Cardiac Physiologists to encourage and support “life long learning” as identified in each staffs' individual appraisal.
All training and educational needs are highlighted in staff annual appraisals and are documented in each individual's Personal Development Programme (PDP).

The department has local guidelines, standard operating practices and protocols that are adhered to by all Cardiac Centre staff. These are available on the departmental shared drive for all staff to freely access.

The Cardiac Centre works with Middlesex University supporting the National School of Healthcare Science Cardiology Practitioner Training Programme (PTP). Students are accepted by the department on a block release basis. All students have a named mentor and supervisor who has undergone mentoring and assessment training.
Equality and Diversity

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliant to the Trust's Equality and Diversity Policy. See Appendix 6, Equality Impact Assessment Form (EIA) Form
Contingency Planning

All Cardiac Diagnostic Tests (excluding pacemaker implantation and coronary angiography) work towards maintaining the 6 Week Wait Target from date of receipt of the referral. If referrals are noted by the Cardiology Waiting List Coordinator to be approaching the 6 Weeks limit from date of referral, the principal cardiac physiologist is informed and relevant heads of service so that additional clinics or appointment slots can be added to manage workload to prevent breaches.
Cardiology Consultant Clinic Activity is scheduled to accommodate consultant annual leave whilst still aiming to maintaining the 18 Week Targets.
In the event of Major Incident, Elective Cardiac Consultant Clinic Activity and Diagnostic Tests may be cancelled as directed to support the Hospital during the incident.
If Cardiac Physiology staffing levels are inadequate to run diagnostic tests safely and efficiently clinics will be cancelled and rescheduled to ensure patient and staff safety is maintained.
In the event of IT or Clinical System Failure, Paper documentation will be completed and uploaded when IT/Clinical System connections are re-established.
N.B Please see Cardiac Angiography Suite Operational Policy for Contingency Planning in
the event of internal incident declaration.
Auditing

This policy will be audited annually by the Principal Cardiac Physiologist in conjunction with the Consultant Cardiologists. Any updates to the policy will be undertaken as required following publication of new guidelines, audit feedback or to meet the needs of service provision.
This information will be shared as required with the Cardiac Service Manager.

Breaches of this policy will be reported via the Datix Incident Reporting System as part of the Trust Incident Reporting Policy. Trends that may be identified as a result of reported incidents will be brought to the attention of the Principal Cardiac Physiologist, Consultant Cardiologists and Cardiac Service Manager where appropriate. This includes failure or equipment breakdown that may impair service delivery and efficiency, management of staffing levels and resultant treatment capacity deficits.

Monthly Cardiac Management Meetings are held in which incidents that have been reported via the Datix system are discussed and any identified trends addressed, including those that may require intervention, investigation or escalation to the Trust Executive Team.
Incidents requiring immediate feedback will be fed back directly to the relevant staff members involved and full dealt with appropriately and in a timely manner.
All Departmental Risks are assessed via the Trust Risk Assurance Framework and Risk Assessments put in place to minimise risk to both staff and patients.
Risk Assessments are reviewed as necessary to ensure they remain relevant and up to date.
Departmental Cardiac Physiology staff meetings are held weekly (Thursday 13.00-

13.30) to provide opportunity to feedback to staff and discuss any incidents that may have occurred. Departmental meetings also provide the facility to share best practice, shape service development and actively monitor departmental risks and performance.

Services within the Cardiac Centre are audited regular by relevant heads of service to ensure all standards are being met consistently in line with guidance and to ensure service delivery is being provided in the most efficient and effective manner. Feedback from audit is provided to staff to help with professional development, improvement of patient experience and ensure quality of care is maintained.

Patient Information Leaflets are audited at least annually by relevant heads of service and altered appropriately based on changes to service provision, clinical management information and patient survey feedback.

Does this item have any differential impact on the equality groups listed? Brief description of impact.
How is this impact being addressed?
Areas in which patients are admitted are not strictly single sex but are in accordance with the single sex policy. .

The Division strive to meet the same sex accommodation standards. The Bathrooms and Staff Changing Facilities have appropriate gender signs. Patients that require a preference of a male or female physiologist for their diagnostic test are allowed to request this upon receipt of their appointment by contacting the department. Chaperones can also be requested by patients.
Language may be seen as a barrier for some patients.
Interpreters are made available when required either face to face or via the language line. All staff complete mandatory training courses regarding Equality and Diversity.
There may be patients, carers or staff who have a disability who use, visit or work within the above service area.

The clinical areas are easily accessible by both stairs and lifts to accommodate those who may use a wheelchair. There is type talk available. Sign language interpreters and type talk can be requested/booked if required. All staff carry out moving and handling in line with patient needs, trust protocol, moving and handling plans and perform risk assessments when necessary.
Unique to each individual and dependent on patient, carer or staff needs and/or requirements.
There is access to the chaplaincy team who are available to offer advice and support for staff, patients and relatives and/or carers.

Written information is available in the clinical areas provided by the chaplaincy team and a chapel is available within the hospital which is accessible to patients, relatives, carers and staff. It is possible to access multi-faith leaders when required.
All people who use, visit or work within the service are treated the same regardless of their sexual orientation.
All staff attend mandatory training regarding Equality and Diversity. Any issues or complaints are fully investigated and responded to within 28 days where appropriate.
Although the department is predominantly an adult service, we do occasionally have paediatric patients referred for some diagnostic tests.

We do not currently have a separate waiting area for children who come for diagnostic tests, but there is a small play area to facilitate children in the waiting room and all children are to be accompanied by a responsible adult at all times whilst in the department/during diagnostic tests.

Offer information on public transport to patients, relatives, carers and escorts travelling to Broomfield Hospital. Patients may be legible for hospital transport if there is a clinical need.
